attributes.title: Gender threat, centrality, voice
attributes.description: 2-part online study with gender identity threat manipulation in part 2. Investigating the interactive effect of gender identity threat and gender identity centrality on automatic voice and voice behavior.

q2.value:
1.	Gender identity threat is positively related to automatic voice.
2.	Gender identity centrality strengthens the positive effect of gender identity threat on automatic voice.
3.	Automatic voice mediates the interactive positive effect of gender identity threat and gender identity centrality on voice.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2-part online study. Part 2 includes 2 conditions of identity threat - high identity threat vs. low identity threat.

q7.value: We are estimating there will be approximately 50% female, 50% male. For part 2, within each of the females and males, Qualtrics will randomly assign 1/2 to the threat condition and ½ to the no threat condition.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1.	We are recruiting undergraduate students enrolled in several business classes at a large university in the Western U.S. to participate in a 2-part study.
2.	The instructors of the class will announce the participation in the study as an extra credit opportunity. 
3.	In Part 1 of the study, students take a 10 minute online study with the moderator variables. In Part 2 of the study, students take a 20 minute online study that includes the manipulation and the rest of the variables. 
4.	Students receive 1% of their overall class grade as extra credit for participating in completing both parts of the study. 
5.	The study timeline: part 1 of the survey launches Apr 6, 2020 and part 2 of the study launches Apr 13, 2020.

q11.value: There are approximately 614 students enrolled in the classes for which extra credit is being offered.

q12.value: Our sample size is based on how many students are enrolled in all of the classes that are being offered extra credit.

q13.value: We will terminate data collection at 5 pm Fri, Apr 17, 2020. This is the due date that students are given for the extra credit.

question.value:
In Part 2 of the study, we will manipulate gender identity threat. At the beginning of the survey, subjects will indicate their gender (we also offer the option of selecting “other” and then ask participants if they identify more with being male or female). Subjects who are female or identify more with being female will receive a survey flow with “female” piped into questions, and subjects who are male or identify more with being male will receive a survey flow with “male” piped into questions.

In the female survey flow, participants will be randomly assigned to one of two levels: high identity threat vs. low identity threat:

High female identity threat:

Despite efforts, gender equality – equal status between men and women – has not been achieved at [college name].

Sexist behavior on [college name]’s campus continues to exist by both students and professors. Women continue to be discriminated against and treated with prejudice. For example, women are judged based on appearances rather than their accomplishments, and their achievements are not attributed to their abilities. In general, fellow students and professors pay more attention to men than women when they speak, and men often interrupt or talk over women or over-explain things to women as if women have no understanding of the issue. Women are also the target of sexist remarks and jokes. For example, women who take a leadership role or are assertive are called “too bossy”. In general, women are conceptualized as weak, delicate, incompetent, and therefore inferior to men.


Low identity threat:

After years of effort, gender equality – equal status between men and women – has improved at [college name].

There is an equal number of women and men enrolled at [college name]. Women and men are being supported equally on campus. For example, colleges spend money supporting programs for both women and men, and the number of women and men have become more similar within a range of majors and disciplines. Women and men are also treated more equally by both students and professors. For example, the achievements of both women and men are attributed to their abilities. In general, fellow students and professors pay equal attention to women and men when they speak. Employers include both female and male candidates when recruiting for jobs. In general, both men and women are viewed as competent, strong, and smart at universities.

In the male survey flow, participants will be randomly assigned to one of two levels: high identity threat vs. low identity threat.


High male identity threat:

In recent years, the discrimination against men has grown at [college name].

Men are being discriminated against on [college name]’s campus. Colleges spend money supporting Women’s Studies programs and encouraging women to study STEM disciplines but no money is spent to support Men’s Studies programs or encourage men to study majors predominantly studied by women. In general, colleges create special scholarships for women and encourage employers to include female candidates when recruiting for jobs. Another example is the elimination of some of the most commonly played sports by men on college campuses as a result of Title IX. Men are also held to a different standard than women. For example, men are treated more harshly in campus disciplinary actions and are often denied rights provided to all Americans off campus. In general, men are at a disadvantage at universities.

Low identity threat for male survey flow is the same as low identity threat for female survey flow.

Moderators (Part 1):
I.	Identity centrality: mean of 10 items focused on either “woman” or “man” identity

1.	Being a woman/man is important in how I define myself.
2.	Being a woman/man is an important reflection of who I am.
3.	I often behave in accordance with being a woman/man.
4.	Overall, being a woman/man has very little to do with how I feel about myself.
5.	In general, being a woman/man is an important part of my self-image.
6.	Being a woman/man is unimportant to my sense of what kind of person I am.
7.	Being a woman/man is central to my identity.
8.	Being a woman/man is an important part of how I see myself.
9.	The fact that I am a woman/man is an important part of my identity.
10.	Being a woman/man is central to my self-concept.

Mediators (Part 2):
II. Voice automaticity will be measured in 7 ways:
A. Time it takes subjects to click on the “yes” button when asked “Would you like to provide ideas on improving gender inequality on [college name]’s campus?”
B. Time it takes subjects to begin typing in the text box referred to below in III (outcomes)
C. Voice automaticity scale: mean of 7 items

1.	I expressed my gender-inequality ideas automatically.
2.	I expressed my gender-inequality ideas without having to consciously decide to do so.
3.	It would make me feel weird if I did not express my gender-inequality ideas.
4.	I expressed my gender-inequality ideas without thinking.
5.	I expressed my gender-inequality ideas because it would require effort not to do it.
6.	I started expressing my gender-inequality ideas before realizing that I was doing it.
7.	I would find it hard to not express my gender-inequality ideas.

D. Voice effort: mean of 4 items

1.	I did not put a lot of effort into thinking about whether to voice my gender-inequality ideas; I just voiced.
2.	It was important for me to think about whether to voice my gender-inequality ideas carefully before speaking up (R)
3.	I didn’t put much energy into considering whether to voice my gender-inequality ideas; I spoke up immediately. 
4.	I didn’t think about whether to voice my gender-inequality ideas because I spoke up automatically.


E. Control effort: mean of 3 items

1.	I put a lot of effort toward controlling myself so that I wouldn’t express my gender-inequality ideas even though I wanted to. 
2.	I was determined not to express my gender-inequality ideas despite my desire to do so. 
3.	It was difficult for me to not speak up about my gender-inequality ideas. 


F. Difficulty controlling voice: mean of 3 items

1.	I found it difficult to overrule my impulse to express my gender-inequality ideas just now.
2.	It was difficult to control my tendency to express my gender-inequality ideas just now.
3.	It was hard to restrain my urge to express my gender-inequality ideas just now.


G. Participants’ thoughts while deciding whether to voice. We will ask participants:

“Please describe what you were thinking when sharing your ideas for gender equality/inequality on [college name] campus. Please be as honest as possible.” 

We will code whether participants’ are thinking about the potential costs of voicing, or whether they are thinking about what to voice. This is consistent with Wood, Quinn, and Kashy’s (2002) methodology. 

Outcomes
III. Whether subjects write ideas in the textbox when given the following prompt:

Female identity threat condition:
“Earlier you read about gender inequality on university campuses. [college name] prides itself on being a diverse campus so [college name] would like to implement some actions to ensure equality across genders. Please share your ideas with [college name]’s Office of Equity and Diversity for what [college name] should do to ensure gender equality on campus.”

Male identity threat condition:
“Earlier you read about male discrimination on university campuses. [college name] prides itself on being a diverse campus so [college name] would like to implement some actions to ensure equality across genders. Please share your ideas with [college name]’s Office of Equity and Diversity for what [college name] should do to ensure gender equality on campus.”

No identity threat condition:
“Earlier you read about gender equality on university campuses. [college name] prides itself on being a diverse campus so [college name]  would like to implement some actions to ensure equality across genders. Please share your ideas with [college name]’s Office of Equity and Diversity for what [college name] should do to ensure gender equality on campus.”



“It is important for you to note that you are still not obligated to provide ideas. In other words, you may skip this step entirely, complete the rest of the survey, and leave.”

Our dependent variable will be whether they voice or not. If they don’t actually provide an idea, they will be coded as not voicing. Participants who write unrelated content will also be coded as ‘not voicing.’

Control variables:
A. Have ideas: mean of 2 items
1.	I have ideas on how to improve the gender-inequality issue on [college name] campus.
2.	I have ideas on how to prevent gender inequality in [college name].

B. Image risk: mean of 3 items
1. By expressing my gender-inequality ideas, my image at [college name]  will be hurt.
2. By expressing my gender-inequality ideas, others at [college name]  will think worse of me.
3. By expressing my gender-inequality ideas, my reputation at [college name] would suffer.

C. Voice efficacy: mean of 3 items
1.	I was confident in my ability to express my gender-inequality ideas.
2.	I was self-assured about my capabilities to express my gender-inequality ideas.
3.	I have mastered the skills necessary to express my gender-inequality ideas.
We will use time in seconds or calculate the average of items as specified above in the “measured variables” section.

1.	We will use one-way ANOVA to compare the threat/no threat cells within the female condition. We will use a separate one-way ANOVA to compare the threat/no threat cells within the male condition. 

The dependent variable in each ANOVA is the response to the question:

The issue you read about was threatening to women/men.

The independent variable is whether they were in the threat or no threat condition. 

2.	We will use path analysis in Mplus to test each hypothesis. We will exclude all participants who do not pass the 1 attention check embedded in the survey and who do not correctly recall the topic of the issue they read about. We will test each moderated mediation hypothesis separately.
3.	We will use R to test each moderated mediation hypothesis in our path analysis and generate 95% confidence intervals for the indirect effects.
4. We will conduct simple slopes analyses for significant interactions in the path analysis.

q18.value: We will center the independent and moderator variables.

q19.value:
1.	We will consider the p-value of the path analysis described above to be significant if < .05, and marginal if .05-.10. We will use two tailed tests.
2.	For the mediation hypothesis, we will consider it to be supported if the 95%CI does not include 0.
3.	We will consider the p-value of the ANOVA model described above to be significant if < .05, and marginal if < .10 but greater than equal to .05. We will use two tailed tests.

q20.value: Data will be excluded for participants who have failed the 1 attention check and for those who have no variance in responses (e.g., answers “3” for all items) and who do not correctly recall the topic of the issue they read about.

q21.value: Missing data will be specified as missing within SPSS. SPSS uses listwise deletion.

q22.value:
1.	For the textbox referred to in III (outcomes), we will explore those responses by coding for the number of ideas proposed, quality of the ideas, whether the ideas are promotive vs. prohibitive. 
2. As exploratory analyses, we will also explore the main effect of our manipulation on mediators and outcome variables using one-way ANOVA (i.e., no mediation).

attributes.title: The Stability of Infant Physiological Reactivity from Seven to 18 Months
attributes.description:
Physiological reactivity refers to changes in the body in response to environmental stimuli. For the purpose of this study, the parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) will be discussed as a measurement of physiological reactivity. The PNS is a marker of physiological arousal and regulation when individuals are faced with stressful or challenging situations in the environment (Beauchaine, 2001). Researchers can reliably measure PNS activity through respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA), which reflects the variation of heart rate during the respiration cycle (Barbosa, Beeghly, Moreira, Tronick & Fuentes, 2018; Beauchaine, 2001). RSA is driven by  the withdrawal or activation of the vagus nerve. During stressful or challenging states, the vagus nerve withdraws its influence on heart rate, thus allowing an increase in heart rate and a decrease in RSA (Porges, 2003).
	
Extensive research has explored the associations between infants’ physiological responses to stress and their caregiving experiences, attachment patterns, and emotion regulation abilities (Barbosa et al., 2018; Beauchaine, 2001; Conradt & Ablow, 2010; Ham & Tronick, 2009; Holochwost, Gariépy, Propper, Mills, & Moore, 2014; Moore, Cohn & Campbell, 2001; Moore, Hill-Soderlund, Propper, Calkins, Mills-Koonce, & Cox, 2009). However, little is known about infants’ autonomic response trajectories across time. One study that has examined these longitudinal patterns is Alkon, Lippert, Vujan, Rodriguez, Boyce and Eskenazi (2006), which measured infants’ RSA during stressful and resting states at six and 12 months. Their results demonstrated that although infants’ RSA responses increased with development, infants’ individual rank order was relatively stable within that time frame. Further, Jewell, Suk and Luecken (2018) studied infants’ RSA trajectories from six weeks to two years of age. However, because only baseline activity was used for their analyses, this study lacked RSA reactivity during states of arousal.

The Still Face Paradigm (SFP) is commonly used to assess physiological responses to resting and challenging states of arousal for infants between the ages of four and nine months (Barbosa et al., 2018; Braugart-Rieker, Zentall, Lickenbrock, Ekas, Oshio, & Planalp, 2014; Conradt & Ablow, 2010; Holochwost et al., 2014; Moore, Cohn & Campbell, 2001; Moore et al., 2009). The standard SFP consists of three episodes (play, still-face, and recovery) in which the caregiver is instructed to either interact with their infant as they normally would or hold a neutral facial expression (Conradt & Ablow, 2010). Infants’ RSA levels tend to decrease be-tween play and still-face episodes as the infant becomes distressed in response to the caregiver’s neutral facial expression. Although RSA levels typically return to baseline levels between still-face and recovery episode (Barbosa et al., 2018; Conradt & Ablow, 2010; Ham & Tronic, 2009; Holochwost et al., 2014; Jones-Mason, Alkon, Coccia, & Bush, 2018; Moore & Calkins, 2004; Moore et al., 2009; Qu & Leerkes, 2017; Weinberg & Tronick, 1996), the rate of recovery can depend on a variety of parent-child factors such as attention, parental sensitivity and socioeco-nomic status (Conradt & Ablow, 2010; Jones-Mason et al., 2018; Moore et al., 2009).

The Strange Situation Procedure (SSP) is commonly used to assess physiological responses to stress for infants between the ages of 12 and 24 months. The SSP consists of eight episodes (1: baseline; 2: mother-child play, 3: mother-child-stranger; 4: child-stranger [1st separation]; 5: mother-child reunion; 6: child alone [2nd separation]; 7: child-stranger; and 8: child-mother reunion; Qu & Leerkes, 2017; Smith, Woodhouse, Clark, & Skowron, 2016). Infants’ RSA levels typically decrease from baseline starting on episode 5 reach the lowest point during episode 7, and then increase and partially recover during the final episode (Hill-Soderlund, Mills-Koonce, Propper Calkins, Granger, Moore, Gariepy, & Cox, 2008; Kohler-Dauner, Roder, Krause, Buchheim, Gündel, Fegert, Ziegenhain, & Walter, 2019; Roder, Koehler-Dauner, Krause, Prinz, Rottler, Alkon, Kolassa, Gündel, Fegert, Ziegenhain, & Walter, 2020; Smith et al., 2016).
	
To our knowledge, no studies have examined the longitudinal associations between pat-terns of RSA reactivity during the SFP and the SSP. Assessing these longitudinal patterns will provide researchers with a deeper understanding of the stability of physiological patterns during this important developmental period. With this in mind, the present study aims to investigate whether infant’s mean RSA levels at seven months of age during the SPF predict mean RSA levels at 18 months of age during the SSP.

q1.value: Tracey Tacana, Bailey Speck, Lee Raby

q2.value:
First, we expect infants’ mean RSA levels will decrease during the still-face episodes compared to the play episode and then increase during the recovery episodes. However, we expect that the overall reactivity from the play episode to the final recovery should show a mean level decrease in RSA throughout the task.  

Second, during the SSP, we similarly expect infants’ RSA levels will show a mean de-crease during the separation episodes compared to the play episode and then increase during reunion episodes. Again, we expect that the overall reactivity from the first play episode to the final reunion will show a mean decrease in RSA throughout the task.

Third, we hypothesize that infants’ mean RSA reactivity across each task will increase from seven months of age to 18 months age.

Fourth, we hypothesize that infant’s patterns of mean RSA reactivity during the SFP will predict mean RSA reactivity patterns during the SSP approximately one year later. For instance, if an infant’s mean RSA reactivity was very low during the reunion episodes of the still face paradigm, we expect them to also have a very low mean RSA level during the reunion episodes of the strange situation.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is part of a broader longitudinal study focused on the psycho-physiological development of 162 mother-child dyads. Mothers were recruited during the third trimester of pregnancy, and the mothers and their biological infants were followed for three years. However, the current study only focuses on children’s physiological data collected at seven months of age during the Still Face Paradigm and at eighteen months of age during the Strange Situation.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: As previously mentioned, this study is part of a broader longitudinal study that is ongoing. Although other manuscripts have been published or are in the processes of being written, longitudinal patterns of RSA reactivity have not been examined thus far. These data remain in their most raw form in separate datasets. I therefore am not aware of any patterns involving the data that will be used for the present study.

question.value:
As described by Lin, Kaliush, Conradt, Terrell, Neff, Allen, Smid, Monk & Crowell, (2019), recruitment for this study was carried out from January 2016 to October 2018. Research assistants recruited pregnant women who were receiving prenatal care at University of Utah associated OBGYN clinics. Pregnant women were also recruited through flyers, brochures, and social media posts. These recruited women and their infants participated in study visits beginning with a prenatal visit, followed by a post-birth hospital visit, a seven-month lab visit, an 18-month lab visit, and finally an 18-month home visit. 

For the purpose of this study, only data collected at the seven and 18-month lab visits will be used. At the seven-month lab visit, electrodes intended to measure cardiac and respiratory activity were placed on mothers and their infants. Mothers were then instructed to complete the Still Face Paradigm (SFP). The SFP is a task that consists of seven episodes and is designed to elicit a distress response from the child. Families were compensated $50 for their participation in this seven-month lab visit. 

At the 18-month lab visit, electrodes intended to measure cardiac and respiratory activity were placed on mothers and their infants. Mothers were then instructed to complete the Strange Situation (SSP). The SSP consists of eight episodes and is designed to elicit stress response from the child. Participants were compensated an additional $50 for participating in this 18-month lab visit.

q11.value: Our sample will include 75 mother-child dyads who completed lab visits when the infant  was seven and 18 months. Mothers are on average 30.76, SD=5.11, years of age and predominately Caucasian (46.7% White, 1.3% African American, 8% Asian American, 21.30% Hispanic, 2.70% Native American, 9.30% Other/Multiracial, and 10.70% did not report ethnicity), middle-class (29.30% of the families had an annual income of [$40 - $79,999]; 8% [< $9,000]; 4% [$15,000-$19,999]; 2.7% [$20,000-$24,999]; 2.7% [$25,000-$29,999]; 4% [$30,000-$39,999]; 5.30% [$40,000-$49,999]; 8% [$80,000-$99,999]; 25% [$100,000 or more]; and 10.7% did no report their income), married (73.30% married, 8% dating or engaged, 8% not in a relationship, and 10.7% did not report their relationship status) women with some college education (34.70% some college, 1.3% less than high school degree, 6.7% high school degree or GED, 26.7% baccalaureate degree, 20% post-baccalaureate degree and 10.7% did not report their education level). Children are also predominately Caucasian (48% White, 1.3% Asian American, 21.3% His-panic, 18.7% Other/Multiracial, and 10.7% did not report the infant’s ethnicity), 48% male,  41.30% female, and 10.7% did not report the infant’s biological gender.

q12.value: The sample size of 75 represents the currently cleaned and available data as of March 25, 2020.

q13.value: The proposed study will use data collected up until March 25, 2020. This termination date was developed in light of pending conference deadlines.

question.value: None

Infants’ mean RSA activity will be measured during the Still Face Paradigm (SFP), which was completed when infants were approximately age 7 months. The SPF consists of three (play, still-face, recover), two minutes episodes, and was designed by Tronick, Adamson, Als, and Brazelton (1975) to elicit distress response from children two to nine months of age (Adamson, & Prick, 2003; Tronick et al., 1975). Starting with the play episode, the mother is instructed to engage in positive interactions with her child during which baseline RSA reactivity is established. Following play, the mother is instructed to hold a neutral facial expression (unresponsive), which usually results in the child becoming distressed, providing us with RSA during a challenging state. Lastly, during the recovery episode, mother is instructed to become responsive to their infant, often trying to soothe them. We can then determine if the child is able to recover to baseline RSA reactivity. 

Infants’ RSA activity will be measured during the Strange Situation Procedure (SSP), which was completed when infants were approximately age 18 months. The SSP consists of eight, three-minute episodes: baseline, free play, stranger, separation 1 (child with stranger), reunion 1, separation 2 (child alone), child with stranger, and reunion 2. The SSP was designed by Mary Ainsworth based on John Bowlby’s theory of attachment (Ainsworth, 1973). The SSP was designed to elicit separation anxiety and stranger anxiety in one-year old infants. During baseline, mother is walked into a room and then left alone with their child. During free play, mother is instructed to sit in a chair and let her child play with toys, and advised to only interact with their child if they seek her attention. Then, during the stranger episode, a stranger comes into the room and quietly sits for one minute, engages with mom for another minute, and tries to engage with baby on the last minute of the episode as the mother leaves the room, marking the start of separation 1 (child with stranger). The stranger tries to play, comfort or distract the child, cutting the episode if the child can’t be comforted. During reunion 1, mother enters the room and pauses in the doorway for the child to respond to her, while the stranger leaves. Moth-er is instructed to leave the child alone during separation 2 to continue playing with toys for the entire episode, unless they become too distressed. The stranger comes in and behaves like they did during the stranger episode, finishing the episode if the child becomes inconsolable. Last, reunion 2 takes place when mother comes in and engages with their child (Ainsworth, 1970).

RSA will be collected through sensors attached to the infant’s torso. Physiological signals are checked throughout the task to ensure that heart rate and respiration data are accurately measured. After data collection, Mindware’s Heart Rate Variability (HRV) software will be used to clean the echocardiograph (ECG) data and extract information about RSA levels. RSA reactivity will then be analyzed to compare reactivity for both lab visits.

To account for infants who were not able to complete the second still face and reunion episodes, as they became too distressed by the first still face and reunion episodes, we will average each infant’s RSA activity measures recovery one and recovery two, thus gathering the most accurate RSA reaction for all infants. We will also average RSA reactivity scores for both Strange Situation reunion episodes to ensure consistent methodological decisions across tasks. 

To create a measure of overall reactivity during the SFP, we will subtract mean RSA activity during the recovery episodes from mean RSA reactivity during the first play episode. To create a measure of overall reactivity during the SSP, we will subtract mean RSA activity during the reunion episodes from mean RSA during the parent-child play episode.

For our first hypothesis, we will calculate infants’ mean RSA activity during both still face episodes, and we will be calculating infants’ mean RSA activity during both recovery episodes. We will then run a dependent samples t-test to assess the differences in RSA between the still face episodes and play episode, and an additional dependent samples t-test will be run to assess the differences in RSA between the still face episodes and the recovery episodes.

For our second hypothesis, we will calculate children’s mean RSA activity during both separation episodes of the Strange Situation, and we will calculate children’s mean RSA activity during both reunion episodes of the Strange Situation. We will then run a dependent samples t-test to assess the differences in RSA between the separations and play episode and an additional dependent samples t-test will be run to assess the differences in RSA between the separation episodes and the reunion episodes. 

For our third hypothesis, we will use the calculated mean RSA reactivity scores for each task to run an additional dependent samples t-test to assess whether there is a significant increase in RSA reactivity between the 7-month Still-Face and the 18-month Strange Situation Procedure. 

Finally, to test our fourth hypothesis we will run a Pearson’s correlation coefficient between seven and 18-month mean RSA reactivity measures to assess the association be-tween seven and 18-month data. All data will be analyzed using SPSS Statistics Software.

q19.value:
Statistical significance for the first three hypotheses will be determined using a two-tailed p value of less than .05 for all t-tests. 

Statistical significance for the fourth hypothesis will be determined using a one-tailed test with a p-value of .05. Any results above a p-value of .05 will be considered not statistically significant. Separate correlation models will be used to address specific hypotheses. A one-tail test is appropriate here to test our directional hypothesis predicting increase of RSA reactivity from seven to 18 months.

q20.value: We will exclude any cases that required manual cleaning of greater than 50% of the physiological data. We will also exclude data with equipment failure, child removing or pulling the electrodes, and data from episodes that were unable to be collected. We will exclude any cases that did not have both seven and 18-month physiological data because our hypotheses include tasks performed at both ages. Lastly, we will identify and exclude outliers from cases where RSA responses were greater than three standard deviations above or below the mean in a manner similar to previous research (Alkon et al., 2011; Conradt & Ablow, 2010; Smith et al., 2016).

q21.value: Missing data will be dealt with using listwise deletion.

q22.value: We will run exploratory analyses assessing mean HR reactivity throughout each episode of the SFP and SSP. As per The Polygaval Theory (Porgues, 2003), HR and RSA are inversely correlated. Therefore, assessing patterns of HR reactivity will contribute to the robustness of the expected RSA findings.

registration_responses.q2:
First, we expect infants’ mean RSA levels will decrease during the still-face episodes compared to the play episode and then increase during the recovery episodes. However, we expect that the overall reactivity from the play episode to the final recovery should show a mean level decrease in RSA throughout the task.  

Second, during the SSP, we similarly expect infants’ RSA levels will show a mean de-crease during the separation episodes compared to the play episode and then increase during reunion episodes. Again, we expect that the overall reactivity from the first play episode to the final reunion will show a mean decrease in RSA throughout the task.

Third, we hypothesize that infants’ mean RSA reactivity across each task will increase from seven months of age to 18 months age.

Fourth, we hypothesize that infant’s patterns of mean RSA reactivity during the SFP will predict mean RSA reactivity patterns during the SSP approximately one year later. For instance, if an infant’s mean RSA reactivity was very low during the reunion episodes of the still face paradigm, we expect them to also have a very low mean RSA level during the reunion episodes of the strange situation.

registration_responses.q6.question: This study is part of a broader longitudinal study focused on the psycho-physiological development of 162 mother-child dyads. Mothers were recruited during the third trimester of pregnancy, and the mothers and their biological infants were followed for three years. However, the current study only focuses on children’s physiological data collected at seven months of age during the Still Face Paradigm and at eighteen months of age during the Strange Situation.
registration_responses.q10.question:
As described by Lin, Kaliush, Conradt, Terrell, Neff, Allen, Smid, Monk & Crowell, (2019), recruitment for this study was carried out from January 2016 to October 2018. Research assistants recruited pregnant women who were receiving prenatal care at University of Utah associated OBGYN clinics. Pregnant women were also recruited through flyers, brochures, and social media posts. These recruited women and their infants participated in study visits beginning with a prenatal visit, followed by a post-birth hospital visit, a seven-month lab visit, an 18-month lab visit, and finally an 18-month home visit. 

For the purpose of this study, only data collected at the seven and 18-month lab visits will be used. At the seven-month lab visit, electrodes intended to measure cardiac and respiratory activity were placed on mothers and their infants. Mothers were then instructed to complete the Still Face Paradigm (SFP). The SFP is a task that consists of seven episodes and is designed to elicit a distress response from the child. Families were compensated $50 for their participation in this seven-month lab visit. 

At the 18-month lab visit, electrodes intended to measure cardiac and respiratory activity were placed on mothers and their infants. Mothers were then instructed to complete the Strange Situation (SSP). The SSP consists of eight episodes and is designed to elicit stress response from the child. Participants were compensated an additional $50 for participating in this 18-month lab visit.
registration_responses.q14.question: None
registration_responses.q15.question:
Infants’ mean RSA activity will be measured during the Still Face Paradigm (SFP), which was completed when infants were approximately age 7 months. The SPF consists of three (play, still-face, recover), two minutes episodes, and was designed by Tronick, Adamson, Als, and Brazelton (1975) to elicit distress response from children two to nine months of age (Adamson, & Prick, 2003; Tronick et al., 1975). Starting with the play episode, the mother is instructed to engage in positive interactions with her child during which baseline RSA reactivity is established. Following play, the mother is instructed to hold a neutral facial expression (unresponsive), which usually results in the child becoming distressed, providing us with RSA during a challenging state. Lastly, during the recovery episode, mother is instructed to become responsive to their infant, often trying to soothe them. We can then determine if the child is able to recover to baseline RSA reactivity. 

Infants’ RSA activity will be measured during the Strange Situation Procedure (SSP), which was completed when infants were approximately age 18 months. The SSP consists of eight, three-minute episodes: baseline, free play, stranger, separation 1 (child with stranger), reunion 1, separation 2 (child alone), child with stranger, and reunion 2. The SSP was designed by Mary Ainsworth based on John Bowlby’s theory of attachment (Ainsworth, 1973). The SSP was designed to elicit separation anxiety and stranger anxiety in one-year old infants. During baseline, mother is walked into a room and then left alone with their child. During free play, mother is instructed to sit in a chair and let her child play with toys, and advised to only interact with their child if they seek her attention. Then, during the stranger episode, a stranger comes into the room and quietly sits for one minute, engages with mom for another minute, and tries to engage with baby on the last minute of the episode as the mother leaves the room, marking the start of separation 1 (child with stranger). The stranger tries to play, comfort or distract the child, cutting the episode if the child can’t be comforted. During reunion 1, mother enters the room and pauses in the doorway for the child to respond to her, while the stranger leaves. Moth-er is instructed to leave the child alone during separation 2 to continue playing with toys for the entire episode, unless they become too distressed. The stranger comes in and behaves like they did during the stranger episode, finishing the episode if the child becomes inconsolable. Last, reunion 2 takes place when mother comes in and engages with their child (Ainsworth, 1970).

RSA will be collected through sensors attached to the infant’s torso. Physiological signals are checked throughout the task to ensure that heart rate and respiration data are accurately measured. After data collection, Mindware’s Heart Rate Variability (HRV) software will be used to clean the echocardiograph (ECG) data and extract information about RSA levels. RSA reactivity will then be analyzed to compare reactivity for both lab visits.
registration_responses.q16.question:
To account for infants who were not able to complete the second still face and reunion episodes, as they became too distressed by the first still face and reunion episodes, we will average each infant’s RSA activity measures recovery one and recovery two, thus gathering the most accurate RSA reaction for all infants. We will also average RSA reactivity scores for both Strange Situation reunion episodes to ensure consistent methodological decisions across tasks. 

To create a measure of overall reactivity during the SFP, we will subtract mean RSA activity during the recovery episodes from mean RSA reactivity during the first play episode. To create a measure of overall reactivity during the SSP, we will subtract mean RSA activity during the reunion episodes from mean RSA during the parent-child play episode.
registration_responses.q17.question:
For our first hypothesis, we will calculate infants’ mean RSA activity during both still face episodes, and we will be calculating infants’ mean RSA activity during both recovery episodes. We will then run a dependent samples t-test to assess the differences in RSA between the still face episodes and play episode, and an additional dependent samples t-test will be run to assess the differences in RSA between the still face episodes and the recovery episodes.

For our second hypothesis, we will calculate children’s mean RSA activity during both separation episodes of the Strange Situation, and we will calculate children’s mean RSA activity during both reunion episodes of the Strange Situation. We will then run a dependent samples t-test to assess the differences in RSA between the separations and play episode and an additional dependent samples t-test will be run to assess the differences in RSA between the separation episodes and the reunion episodes. 

For our third hypothesis, we will use the calculated mean RSA reactivity scores for each task to run an additional dependent samples t-test to assess whether there is a significant increase in RSA reactivity between the 7-month Still-Face and the 18-month Strange Situation Procedure. 

Finally, to test our fourth hypothesis we will run a Pearson’s correlation coefficient between seven and 18-month mean RSA reactivity measures to assess the association be-tween seven and 18-month data. All data will be analyzed using SPSS Statistics Software.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of Narrative Exposure Therapy in Patients with Childhood Trauma-Related Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: a Single Case Series  Design
attributes.description: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of Narrative Exposure Therapy (NET) in the treatment of childhood trauma-related posttraumatic stress disorder (CTR-PTSD). Nine adult patients that were on the waiting list for treatment participated. A non-concurrent multiple baseline design was used with a baseline of 4 weeks before treatment started. After baseline, the first session of NET constructs a narrative of participants’ lifeline, incorporating trauma’s and other life events. In subsequent weeks therapists guide the participants through their lifelines. The length of treatment varies depending on the amount and severity of trauma’s. The NET-therapy is followed by a 6 months follow-up. Participants filled in the Posttraumatic Diagnostic Scale (PDS) and Manchester Short Assessment of quality of life (MANSA) after each session. Data were analyzed in R using visual inspection, a mixed model analysis and a time-series analysis.

q2.value:
1.	PTSD symptoms will decrease more during the treatment phase than during the baseline phase. 
2.	MANSA scores will increase more during the treatment phase than during the baseline phase.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A non-concurrent multiple baseline single case analysis

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Data has been collected by means of online questionnaires to the nine participants of the study. Independent interviewers have conducted the interviews before and after the treatment.

question.value: As explained above: Data has been collected by means of online questionnaires to the nine participants of the study. Independent interviewers have conducted the interviews before and after the treatment.

q11.value: We have followed the therapy trajectories of nine participants

q12.value: To obtain enough power for our multiple baseline analysis, we aimed for at least 9 participants in the study.

question.value: All participants completed between 5 and 27 sessions of Narrative Exposure Therapy

Our main outcome variable were the experienced PTSD symptoms (as measured by the Post-traumatic Stress Diagnostic Scale (PDS)).
Our secondary outcome was the quality of life (as measured by the Manchester Short Assessment of Quality of Life (MANSA)).

First, a visual analysis is performed where we will assess the data on basis of its level, trend and variability. Next, a mixed model design will be used using package nlme in R. 

See the data analysis plan for a more elaborate description of the analysis.

q21.value: We handle missing data with maximum likelihood.

q22.value:
The further non-statistical hypotheses we will test in our study are: 
1.	Treatment effects are sustained in follow-up phase
This hypothesis is confirmed when there are no differences between PDS scores at the end of treatment and during follow-up phase or when the scores are even lower during follow-up. 

2.	NET is a feasible therapy, i.e. 
a.	Treatment retention rate is sufficient 
This hypothesis is confirmed when treatment retention rate of NET is similar or higher compared to other PTSD treatments. 
b.	A sufficient number of patients complete the entire NET-protocol. 
This hypothesis is confirmed when NET scores the same or higher compared to other PTSD treatments 

3.	NET is an acceptable therapy 
This will be confirmed when drop-out rates, adverse events and worsening of complaints are  similar or lower compared to other PTSD treatments. Furthermore, it will be investigated whether internal or external factors caused the participants to stop the therapy.

attributes.title: She’s Always A ’Quota Woman’? The Subjective Effects of Gender Quotas
attributes.description: While objective effects of gender quotas have been studies quiet extensively, subjective effects of quotas haven't been studied. This paper tests the subjective effect of gender quotas. In order to test these I employ a survey experiment with party leaders in Austria, Germany and Switzerland. Party leaders are asked to evaluate a female politican based on a audio clip. They will receive information on whether a politican was elected through a gender quota (treatment) or not (control) along other biographical information. Furthermore I will test framing effects by calling the gender quota a quota for women in the first treatment group and a ceiling quota for men in the other treatment group. This paper contributes to the literature on gender quota and the underrepresentation of women.

summary.value:
Theory

Over 100 countries have adopted gender quotas in some form or another, in order to address the systematic descriptive underrepresentation of women (Dahlerup et al., 2013). This form of intervention in the electoral process does not only pose a normative dilemma between the desire to ensure appropriate descriptive representation of women and the democratic principle to have a free, unrestricted choice between candidates, but also has practical implications. The practical consequences of gender quotas like their effect on electoral performance (G´orecki and Kuko lowicz, 2014), candidate quality (Allen, Cutts and Campbell, 2016), and the substantive representation of women (Franceschet and Piscopo, 2008) have been covered by scholars. Yet, surprisingly little effort has been made to study the effect of gender quotas on perception of ”quota-women”. While gender quotas
might not have an adverse impact on the objective quality of female candidates
and MPs, voters and party members might stereotype these candidates and MPs
as ”quota-women” who are not up for the job. The literature on gender quotas
has so far neglected these potential (negative) subjective effects of gender quotas
(Franceschet, Krook and Piscopo, 2012). Yet neglecting these (side)effects of gender quotas can shift focus away from areas in which quotas might have an adverse
effect on the representation of women in politics e.g. career advancement within
political parties and parliament. While the case for gender quotas can be easily be made, as they ”are the most effective way in practice to achieve descriptive representation” (Kittilson, 2005), gender quotas may also have unintended consequences. For example, G´orecki
and Kuko lowicz (2014) show that gender quotas in Poland may have decreased
electoral performances of women. Studies of attitudinal effects of gender quotas,
also show that gender quotas can have negative effects. A noteworthy example is
Clayton (2015), who suggests that gender quotas in Lesotho have actually reduced
women‘s political engagement due to the aversion against the gender quota as
selection mechanism.

These potential negative effects of gender quotas are not surprising, as gender quotas can be perceived as disruptive to the free selection of candidates and MPs in a democratic society. Furthermore gender quotas usually are framed in terms of supporting women achieving equal representation, which effectively establishes male dominance in parliaments as the norm and women in parliament as the deviation (Murray, 2014). In general, quotas also set up a separate competition spaces for men and women: Women compete against other women and men compete against other men. Therefore quotas can be perceived to make the candidate selection less competitive and undermine merit based candidate selection. This potential change in the perception of competitiveness and merit should affect women more than men, as the quotas were introduced to ensure the representation of women and therefore they are the reason why the candidate selection can be perceived as less competitive. Furthermore the underrepresentation of women in parliaments might have led party members and voters to believe, that women are less qualified for the job
because they ”could not handle themselves” in a system with free competition. Quotas can be perceived to ”artificially” increase the chances of candidates that could not handle themselves beforehand. Therefore my first hypothesis is:

H1: Women elected through gender quotas are perceived to be less qualified
than women not elected through gender quotas 

The hypothesised negative effect of gender quotas on women should also manifest itself in the career paths of female politicians. If it is truly the case that
gender quotas negatively impact the assessment of women, than they might not
be considered to be viable candidates for higher political office by political parties.
Breaking through the glass ceiling with the help of a gender quota therefore can
potentially create another glass ceiling in later career stages:

H2: Women elected through gender quotas are less likely to be considered for
higher political office than women not elected through a gender quota


Another potential effect of gender quotas is that they encourage essentialism,
the belief that members of a particular group have a certain essence that nonmembers cannot acquire. In the context of representation this means, that women
can be perceived to be the only individuals that can represent women due to
their essential characteristics, which in turn means that women are not able to
represent men. Quotas enforce gender division by implicitly or explicitly stating
that women should be represented by women (Mansbridge, 2005). This potential
encouragement of essentialism through gender quotas should affect men and women
differently and therefore I propose the following hypotheses:

H3a: Men will feel less represented by a woman elected through a gender quota
than by women not elected through a gender quota

H3b: Women will feel more represented by a woman elected through a gender
quota than by women not elected through a gender quota

I will also test the argument that in order to facilitate the acceptance and counteract potential negative sight effects gender quotas should be framed as quotas for men (Murray 2014). In line with this argument,  I expect potential negative effects of gender quotas to be weaker if the quota is framed as a quota for men. 

H4: Potential negative effects of gender quotas will be weaker if the quota is framed as a quota for men. 

Research Design

In order to asses the hypothesized subjective effects of gender quotas I will employ
a survey experiment. This will allow me to estimate the causal effect of gender
quotas on the perception of female politicians.

Participants will receive information on a MP through a vignette. This text
will contain information on the MPs professional background, parliamentary committee membership, the MPs policy area of expertise and information on when this
female MP was elected to parliament. The treatment that will be manipulated in
this experiment is the information, whether the party of the female MP used a quota or not during nominating her as candidate. More specifically, whether they did not use a quota (no information on quotas provided), which is the control group, a Frauenquote (quota for women), which is the first treatment group or a "Höchstquote für Männer" (ceiling quota for men). 

 After being randomly assigned treatment 1, treatment 2  or control status, the
treatment groups will receive the information that the politicians won a seat in
parliament through a gender quota (male vs female), whereas the control group will not receive any
information on whether the female MP was elected through a quota or not.
In order to make the experimental environment more realistic, I opt to let the
participants listen to an an audio clip of a neutral policy statement of said MP
instead of the very commonly used text information. Audio clips contain additional
information compared to text excerpts. Most importantly, through the sound of
the voice I am able to remind participants that said politicians is actually a women,
which could cue respondents in the treatment group to think more intensely about
gender quotas. Furthermore I will use the statements of real MPs elected through quotas, in order to ensure that it is a realistic statement and setting. Participants will receive a
statement by an unknown MP from a different country, in order to make sure that
they have little prior knowledge on said MP.

The cases and the population of my experiment will be th
party leaders in Austria, Switzerland and Germany. The In all three countries no legal gender quotas exists, but some parties have introduced quotas in their candidate selection process
voluntarily (IDEA, 2018). This provides me with variation regarding the exposure
to gender quotas of the different party leaders.

The dependent variables will be constructed though a questionnaire both the
control and treatment group receive after listening to the audio clip. In this questionnaire participants will be asked to asses whether they think that the legislator
is competent, qualified, is able to substantively represent men and women and
whether they would consider her for higher political office. With this information
the ATE of gender quotas on the perception of female candidates by party leaders
can be calculated. Before being assigned treatment and control status, participants
will be asked to answer questions on their socio-demographic and political characteristics. This will allow me to examine whether a potential effect is contingent
on certain attributes of respondents.

attributes.title: Motivated Reasoning, Government Performance, and COVID 19
attributes.description: This study examines factors that influence the way members of the public attribution blame or credit for the government's response to the spread of the COVID-19 virus in the United States. We look at two factors in particular: 1) equivalence framing, and 2) the name used to describe the virus (COVID - 19 versus the Chinese Virus). NOTE: This study corrects errors found in a previous pre-registered study that were found before data collection began.

q1.value: Gregory Porumbescu, Donald Moynihan, Jason Anastasopoulos, Asmus Leth Olsen

q2.value:
All hypotheses are directional. 

H1: Participants exposed to negatively framed performance data will be more negative in their assessments of the problem (extremely serious) and more negative in their evaluations of actors in the United States Federal Government than participants exposed to positively framed performance data.

H2: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' will be more inclined to blame East Asian residents and the Chinese government when compared to participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19.'

H3: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' and negatively framed performance data will attribute greater blame for the response to the pandemic to East Asian and Chinese residents/Chinese government than participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19' and negatively framed performance data.

H4: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' and negatively framed performance data are less likely to blame the United States Federal Government for the spread of the pandemic than participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19' and negatively framed performance data.


H5: Conservatives/Republicans will be more likely to understate the severity of the problem and blame actors other than the US Federal Government (non-governmental actors, other governments) 

H6: Liberals/Democrats will be more likely to view the problem as serious and blame actors in the US Federal Government more than other actors.

H7: The effect of positively framed performance data on support for actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H8: The effect of negatively framed performance data on blaming actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Liberals/Democrats

H9: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming East Asians/Chinese government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H10: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming actors outside of the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

H1: Participants exposed to negatively framed performance data will be more negative in their assessments of the problem (extremely serious) and more negative in their evaluations of actors in the United States Federal Government than participants exposed to positively framed performance data.

H4: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' and negatively framed performance data are less likely to blame the United States Federal Government for the spread of the pandemic than participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19' and negatively framed performance data.


H5: Conservatives/Republicans will be more likely to understate the severity of the problem and blame actors other than the US Federal Government (non-governmental actors, other governments) 

H6: Liberals/Democrats will be more likely to view the problem as serious and blame actors in the US Federal Government more than other actors.

H7: The effect of positively framed performance data on support for actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H8: The effect of negatively framed performance data on blaming actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Liberals/Democrats

H9: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming East Asians/Chinese government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H10: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming actors outside of the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

attributes.title: Effects of minimal group assignments on resource allocation

summary.value:
In this research, we will examine intergroup bias in resource allocation in minimal group contexts. We will first assign participants to one of two minimal groups using either the dot estimation or artistic preference minimal group paradigm (both adapted from Tajfel et al., 1971). Participants will then complete a resource allocation task designed to measure their intergroup bias (Tajfel et al., 1971). In this task, participants will see a series of six matrices. Each matrix consists of 13 columns with two rows. Participants will then select one column that represents the points to be awarded to two anonymous individuals. One person will share the same group membership as the participant (ingroup), and the other person will have a different group membership (outgroup). Although the six matrices in this research were originally used by Tajfel et al. (1971), the Qualtrics scripts we used for this research were adapted from Loersch & Arbuckle's (2013, Study 1), and like these researchers, we only include ingroup/outgroup allocation decisions (i.e., no ingroup/ingroup or outgroup/outgroup trials). Critically, unlike previous research, we will examine whether the category labels of the groups that participants are assigned to influence the allocation decisions and moderate any intergroup bias. To test this, we will conduct the current research in two different studies.

In the first study, participants will be randomly assigned to the overestimator or underestimator group (Tajfel et al., 1971) using a Numerical Estimation Style Test (Ratner & Amodio, 3013; Ratner et al., 2014) and then they will complete the resource allocation task in reference to overestimator and underestimator targets. We will collect 200 participants using Qualtrics. We will attempt to recruit 100 participants in each minimal group condition (overestimator-ingroup vs. underestimator-ingroup), but we are randomly assigning participants through Qualtrics, thus the number of participants in each condition may not be exactly equal. We will then conduct a 2 (ingroup vs. outgroup) X 2 (overestimator vs. underestimator) mixed design ANOVA on the total number of resources allocated to each group. 

In the second study, participants will be assigned to either the Kandinsky or Klee groups (Tajfel et al., 1971) and complete the resource allocation task for a Klee group member or a Kandinsky group member. We will collect 200 participants using Qualtrics. We will attempt to recruit 100 participants in each minimal group condition (Klee-ingroup vs. Kandinsky-ingroup), but we are randomly assigning participants through Qualtrics, thus the number of participants in each condition may not be exactly equal. We will then conduct 2 (ingroup vs. outgroup) X 2 (Kandinsky vs. Klee) mixed design ANOVA on the total number of resources allocated to each group. 

We will also get ratings of different minimal groups on their likability (1- very negative; 5 - very positive) as well as thirteen trait impressions (Oosterhof & Todorov, 2008). We will examine relationships between these ratings and how participants allocated resources to different groups and category labels.

A note about our sample size determinations:
The Qualtrics script we will use was adapted from Loersch & Arbuckle (2013, Study 1). In Loersch & Arbuckle's study, they used a sample of 76 undergraduate students. Although we felt like their study was the closest to ours for determining potential sample size, our research differs from theirs in important ways. First, our group manipulations are different than theirs. Second, we plan to recruit participants using Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Third, they were interested in general ingroup and outgroup differences and we are interested in group differences, differences due to category labels, and potential interactions between group assignment and category labels. Given these differences between their study and ours, we viewed 76 participants per overestimator-ingroup condition, 76 participants per underestimator-ingroup condition, 76 participants per Kandinsky-ingroup condition, and 76 participants per Klee-ingroup condition as the minimum sample sizes per condition, but based on the resources we were willing to allocate to this research we decided to round-up to approximately 100 participants per condition (depending on random assignment) for a total of 400 participants (200 for Study 1 and 200 for study 2).    

Attached are the Qualtrics scripts we will use for our two studies (Tajfe_Matrices_NEST.qsf -overestimator/underestimator; Tajfe_Matrices_ART.qsf - Kandinsky/Klee)

attributes.title: Endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus and selected aspects of psychosocial functioning during the COVID-19 pandemics
attributes.description: Our study will focus on the link between endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus and several aspects of functioning during the COVID-19 pandemics. We chose a cross-lag model in order to draw conclusions concerning cause-and-effect relationship.

copyright_holders: The items concerning the coronavirus conspiracy theories and the behavior during the pandemics belong to us. The other questionnaires belong to their authors.

q1.value: Agnieszka Ewa Lys, Anna Studzinska, Kamilla Bargiel-matusiewicz, Daniel Pankowski, Tomasz Oleksy, Anna Wnuk

q2.value:
H1: Endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus negatively predicts the level of pro-social behavior.
H2: Endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus as something deliberately created positively predicts the level of pre-traumatic stress symptoms, related to the fear of a COVID-19 infection.
H3:  Endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning information about coronavirus as a hoax negatively predicts the level of pre-traumatic stress symptoms, related to the fear of a COVID-19 infection.
H4: Level of pre-traumatic stress symptoms is positively predicted by superstitious behaviors.
H5: Level of pre-traumatic stress symptoms is positively predicted by some of religious behaviors (those that are not related to meetings in bigger groups).
H6: Level of pro-social behavior during the second measurement (T2) is negatively predicted by endorsement of conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus during the first measurement (T1).
H7: Level of pro-social behavior during the second measurement (T2) is positively predicted by agreeableness during the first measurement (T1).
H8: The regularities described in H1-H3 are moderated by neuroticism and agreeableness.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
