attributes.title: Unlimited leave at a Dutch bank
attributes.description:
This study will test the effects of an unlimited leave policy on employees’ levels of autonomy, work-related well-being (e.g., work-life balance, energy levels) and organizational outcomes (e.g., organizational commitment) at a bank in the Netherlands. Moderating variables (e.g., leadership style, social pressure) and mediating variables (e.g. recovery experiences, distribution of free days over a year) are assessed. Quantitative data includes an online pre-post questionnaire, and monthly assessments over the course of a year in the experimental (participants working under the unlimited leave policy) and two control groups (participants working under the regular leave policy). Face-to-face qualitative interviews will also be conducted with a subgroup of participants from the unlimited leave group several times during the project to understand the crucial steps for the implementation and effectiveness of unlimited leave: e.g., How do employees decide when to take a holiday and for how long? What role does the supervisor or team play in these decisions? 
Assessments takes place from January 2020 to December 2020.

Research questions
This study tests the effects of an unlimited leave policy at a bank in the Netherlands on their employees’ levels of autonomy, work happiness and work-related well-being among other things. Specifically, some of the research questions we aim to address include the following:  

1.	Effects of unlimited holidays
a.	What effects does unlimited leave have on employees? Specifically, do employees benefit from unlimited leave compared to employees who do not have unlimited leave? 
b.	What effects does unlimited leave have on an organization? Specifically, do organizational outcomes improve with unlimited leave compared to the regular leave policy? 
c.	Does unlimited leave have any undesired effects (e.g., elevated work pressure or social conflicts within teams)? 
d.	Does unlimited leave influence employees’ perception of the organization, and foster a cultural change towards autonomy and self-management at the organization?
2.	Role of individual characteristics and work context
a.	Do some employees benefit more from unlimited leave than others, and what are the characteristics of these employees in terms of personal, organizational, task or team variables? 
b.	Are there environmental and organizational factors that support or hinder positive effects of unlimited leave to unfold? 
c.	Regarding organizational factors, which steps of the implementation of unlimited leave are related to the experience of more or less autonomy and employees’ happiness?
3.	Mechanisms
a.	How can the potential beneficial effects of unlimited leave be explained?

q1.value: Jessica De Bloom, Christine Syrek, Jana Kühnel, Tim Vahle-Hinz, Kim Nicole Titlestad, Silvie Pothof

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1. Unlimited leave will improve employees’ general sense of well-being over time (as measured by work-life balance, mental energy and affect) compared to employees with the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 2. Unlimited leave will improve employees’ work-related well-being over time (as measured by job satisfaction, work engagement, mastery, control and autonomy satisfaction) compared to employees with the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 3. Unlimited leave will improve organizational outcomes over time (as measured by organizational citizenship behavior, organizational commitment and job performance) compared to the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 4. Positive effects of unlimited leave (on well-being and organizational outcomes) are mediated by employees’ sense of work autonomy, leave autonomy and recovery experiences derived from the leave as well as leave duration and frequency.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Field experiment. Employees at a bank in the Netherlands were divided into an experimental (working under unlimited leave policy) and control condition (working under regular leave policy). A reference group was randomly selected from the general bank of the Netherlands population (since the managers in the experimental and control conditions self-selected into the pilot). Data is collected through online pre-post questionnaires (for all three groups), and monthly assessments over the course of a year (just for the experimental group and the control group).

q7.value: Randomization into the experimental and control group was not possible given organizational constraints as well as the desire to create a balanced sample. First, managers at the bank were able to choose if they would be willing to allow the employees they supervise to be in the pilot (experimental or control condition). Whether or not they did so was often based on the type of work their employees perform (e.g., call center employees should be more available to clients and thus were not selected to be a part of the pilot). Further, in order to increase the realism of the experiment, it was necessary to have colleagues who work closely together to have the same leave policy. Since much of the work at this particular bank is performed in self-managing teams, larger groups of employees or even departments who depend highly on one another needed to be assigned to the same condition for the study to be both realistic and practical. In the process of randomization, some managers changed their minds about whether they would allow their employees to be in the experimental or control group (e.g., due to upcoming restructuring within the organization). Thus, in the end, randomization was not possible. However, the reference group (who will only receive the pre- and post-measure questionnaire) did consist of a random selection of employees at the bank whose managers did not sign up to be in the pilot.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The first three of twelve waves have already been collected. This is a longitudinal study. Assessment takes place from January 2020 to December 2020. Currently, we have data from January, February and March but have not yet begun analysis. Analyses will take place when all the data has been collected.

question.value: Data is being collected through monthly online questionnaires using the Unipark/Questback platform. Participants are employees at the bank in the Netherlands. Which groups of participants were included in the study was determined by the bank based on internal recruitment procedures (i.e., team leaders were contacted and asked to take part in the research and 54% agreed to allow their employees to take part). Randomization was not possible due to organizational constraints (for more detail, see Randomization below).

q11.value: 303 participants were in the experimental group (working under the unlimited leave policy) at the beginning of the study (January 2020) while 334 participants were in the control group (working under the regular leave policy). 700 participants were invited to be in the reference group (random sample taken from the general bank population without unlimited leave).

q12.value: The sample size was maximized given the organizational constraints of the bank. We tried to get as many participants as possible given drop-out will likely occur over the course of the year.

q13.value: There is no stopping rule. The sample size was set at the beginning of the study.

question.value: Whether employees work under the unlimited leave policy of the bank or work under the regular leave policy.

A set of key variables is included in the study. For most variables, we have clear ideas whether they would likely be DVs, mediators or moderators but for others this would be something we would have to explore in exploratory analysis. Here we list the variables as we conceptualize them now, ordering them by theme and time scale. The time scale is indicated by asterisks: * variables we expect to remain stable, ** variables that may be affected after a long time, *** variables of interest that are expected to change over time, **** variables of key interest that are expected to change rapidly over time. 
	
Dependent variables: General well-being (work-life balance****, mental energy****, affect****), Work-related well-being (work engagement****, job satisfaction****, mastery and control****, autonomy satisfaction****), and Organizational outcomes (job performance***, organizational citizenship behavior****, organizational commitment****).  

Mediating variables: Autonomy (decision making autonomy**, work methods autonomy**, work scheduling autonomy****, work location autonomy****, leave autonomy****), Characteristics of leave taken (agency***, purpose****, frequency****, duration****, quality of leave****).

Moderating variables: Job demands (effort-reward imbalance**, work hours****, work load****), Person characteristics (workaholism (obsessive work drive)*, motivation to comply*, demographical information*, workaholism (unease when not working)***, self-efficacy***), Organizational team culture (team interdependence***, supportive leadership***, social support of colleagues/supervisors***, team fairness****, team leave heterogeneity****, perceived norms regarding leave****, conflicts over leave****, social pressure****).

Note: During the writing of this pre-registration, the COVID-19 pandemic caused interruption in the working lives of employees at the bank (along with the rest of the world). Most employees were forced to work from home. As such, we added a few questions to the March questionnaire and plan to use these measures as a control for any unusual spikes or dips in the data during this period .

Most of the scales were taken from validated measures, while some were generated for the purpose of this research. See Appendix 1 for more details.

Given the nested, longitudinal nature of the data we will conduct a two-level multilevel analysis. Level 1 will be the within person level (monthly measurement occasions are nested within persons) and Level 2 will be the person level. In order to determine what effect the proposed mediators have, we will specifically use multilevel path analysis in R (package: lavaan or nlme) and Mplus.

As mentioned previously, we will control for any unusual spikes or dips in the data during the COVID-19 pandemic using the questions added in March (the third wave).

q19.value: Model selection will be based on minimizing the Bayesian Information Criterion. Effects will be interpreted as significant at the p<0.05 cut off.

q21.value: Multilevel analysis with likelihood-based methods is fairly robust to missing values as long as they are missing at random (MAR). Descriptives of missing values will be calculated (i.e., the number of missing values, how they are distributed across variables and higher level units, how they are distributed across experimental conditions). We do expect drop-out to occur over time and excluding all this data may mean a loss of power. If, from the descriptives, data does appear to be MAR list-wise deletion will be applied. If missingness is not random and models fail to converge, multilevel imputation will be applied.

q22.value:
For the multilevel model, we could explore whether adding a group level to the data is possible: we have access to information about the departments or teams that employees work in. However, due to the agile nature of the organizational structure at this particular bank (i.e., employees change teams quite frequently) we are not yet sure how stable team membership would be and thus how complex such analysis would be – this is only something that could be determined at the end of the year. Furthermore, since there has been little to no research to date on the effects of unlimited leave on employees’ well-being and work-related experiences, we cannot be certain about some of the proposed hypotheses. Specifically, we are interested in the moderating effects of some of the measured variables. Therefore, some exploratory analysis will be necessary. 
Finally, we are also collecting qualitative interview data which we could use to inform the types of exploratory models that we may test. 20 employees will be interviewed throughout the year (in January, April, August and December). The qualitative data will be analyzed using Structuration theory. Themes, such as: expectations and concerns, experienced organizational norms and role models in planning holidays, cultural changes within the organization, ownership and changing social relationships with colleagues or supervisors will be explored.

registration_responses.q1: Jessica De Bloom, Christine Syrek, Jana Kühnel, Tim Vahle-Hinz, Kim Nicole Titlestad, Silvie Pothof
registration_responses.q2:
Hypothesis 1. Unlimited leave will improve employees’ general sense of well-being over time (as measured by work-life balance, mental energy and affect) compared to employees with the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 2. Unlimited leave will improve employees’ work-related well-being over time (as measured by job satisfaction, work engagement, mastery, control and autonomy satisfaction) compared to employees with the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 3. Unlimited leave will improve organizational outcomes over time (as measured by organizational citizenship behavior, organizational commitment and job performance) compared to the regular leave policy.

Hypothesis 4. Positive effects of unlimited leave (on well-being and organizational outcomes) are mediated by employees’ sense of work autonomy, leave autonomy and recovery experiences derived from the leave as well as leave duration and frequency.
registration_responses.q3: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: Randomization into the experimental and control group was not possible given organizational constraints as well as the desire to create a balanced sample. First, managers at the bank were able to choose if they would be willing to allow the employees they supervise to be in the pilot (experimental or control condition). Whether or not they did so was often based on the type of work their employees perform (e.g., call center employees should be more available to clients and thus were not selected to be a part of the pilot). Further, in order to increase the realism of the experiment, it was necessary to have colleagues who work closely together to have the same leave policy. Since much of the work at this particular bank is performed in self-managing teams, larger groups of employees or even departments who depend highly on one another needed to be assigned to the same condition for the study to be both realistic and practical. In the process of randomization, some managers changed their minds about whether they would allow their employees to be in the experimental or control group (e.g., due to upcoming restructuring within the organization). Thus, in the end, randomization was not possible. However, the reference group (who will only receive the pre- and post-measure questionnaire) did consist of a random selection of employees at the bank whose managers did not sign up to be in the pilot.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q9: The first three of twelve waves have already been collected. This is a longitudinal study. Assessment takes place from January 2020 to December 2020. Currently, we have data from January, February and March but have not yet begun analysis. Analyses will take place when all the data has been collected.
registration_responses.q11: 303 participants were in the experimental group (working under the unlimited leave policy) at the beginning of the study (January 2020) while 334 participants were in the control group (working under the regular leave policy). 700 participants were invited to be in the reference group (random sample taken from the general bank population without unlimited leave).
registration_responses.q12: The sample size was maximized given the organizational constraints of the bank. We tried to get as many participants as possible given drop-out will likely occur over the course of the year.
registration_responses.q13: There is no stopping rule. The sample size was set at the beginning of the study.
registration_responses.q19: Model selection will be based on minimizing the Bayesian Information Criterion. Effects will be interpreted as significant at the p<0.05 cut off.
registration_responses.q21: Multilevel analysis with likelihood-based methods is fairly robust to missing values as long as they are missing at random (MAR). Descriptives of missing values will be calculated (i.e., the number of missing values, how they are distributed across variables and higher level units, how they are distributed across experimental conditions). We do expect drop-out to occur over time and excluding all this data may mean a loss of power. If, from the descriptives, data does appear to be MAR list-wise deletion will be applied. If missingness is not random and models fail to converge, multilevel imputation will be applied.
registration_responses.q22:
For the multilevel model, we could explore whether adding a group level to the data is possible: we have access to information about the departments or teams that employees work in. However, due to the agile nature of the organizational structure at this particular bank (i.e., employees change teams quite frequently) we are not yet sure how stable team membership would be and thus how complex such analysis would be – this is only something that could be determined at the end of the year. Furthermore, since there has been little to no research to date on the effects of unlimited leave on employees’ well-being and work-related experiences, we cannot be certain about some of the proposed hypotheses. Specifically, we are interested in the moderating effects of some of the measured variables. Therefore, some exploratory analysis will be necessary. 
Finally, we are also collecting qualitative interview data which we could use to inform the types of exploratory models that we may test. 20 employees will be interviewed throughout the year (in January, April, August and December). The qualitative data will be analyzed using Structuration theory. Themes, such as: expectations and concerns, experienced organizational norms and role models in planning holidays, cultural changes within the organization, ownership and changing social relationships with colleagues or supervisors will be explored.
registration_responses.q6.question: Field experiment. Employees at a bank in the Netherlands were divided into an experimental (working under unlimited leave policy) and control condition (working under regular leave policy). A reference group was randomly selected from the general bank of the Netherlands population (since the managers in the experimental and control conditions self-selected into the pilot). Data is collected through online pre-post questionnaires (for all three groups), and monthly assessments over the course of a year (just for the experimental group and the control group).
registration_responses.q10.question: Data is being collected through monthly online questionnaires using the Unipark/Questback platform. Participants are employees at the bank in the Netherlands. Which groups of participants were included in the study was determined by the bank based on internal recruitment procedures (i.e., team leaders were contacted and asked to take part in the research and 54% agreed to allow their employees to take part). Randomization was not possible due to organizational constraints (for more detail, see Randomization below).
registration_responses.q14.question: Whether employees work under the unlimited leave policy of the bank or work under the regular leave policy.
registration_responses.q15.question:
A set of key variables is included in the study. For most variables, we have clear ideas whether they would likely be DVs, mediators or moderators but for others this would be something we would have to explore in exploratory analysis. Here we list the variables as we conceptualize them now, ordering them by theme and time scale. The time scale is indicated by asterisks: * variables we expect to remain stable, ** variables that may be affected after a long time, *** variables of interest that are expected to change over time, **** variables of key interest that are expected to change rapidly over time. 
	
Dependent variables: General well-being (work-life balance****, mental energy****, affect****), Work-related well-being (work engagement****, job satisfaction****, mastery and control****, autonomy satisfaction****), and Organizational outcomes (job performance***, organizational citizenship behavior****, organizational commitment****).  

Mediating variables: Autonomy (decision making autonomy**, work methods autonomy**, work scheduling autonomy****, work location autonomy****, leave autonomy****), Characteristics of leave taken (agency***, purpose****, frequency****, duration****, quality of leave****).

Moderating variables: Job demands (effort-reward imbalance**, work hours****, work load****), Person characteristics (workaholism (obsessive work drive)*, motivation to comply*, demographical information*, workaholism (unease when not working)***, self-efficacy***), Organizational team culture (team interdependence***, supportive leadership***, social support of colleagues/supervisors***, team fairness****, team leave heterogeneity****, perceived norms regarding leave****, conflicts over leave****, social pressure****).

Note: During the writing of this pre-registration, the COVID-19 pandemic caused interruption in the working lives of employees at the bank (along with the rest of the world). Most employees were forced to work from home. As such, we added a few questions to the March questionnaire and plan to use these measures as a control for any unusual spikes or dips in the data during this period .

Most of the scales were taken from validated measures, while some were generated for the purpose of this research. See Appendix 1 for more details.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Given the nested, longitudinal nature of the data we will conduct a two-level multilevel analysis. Level 1 will be the within person level (monthly measurement occasions are nested within persons) and Level 2 will be the person level. In order to determine what effect the proposed mediators have, we will specifically use multilevel path analysis in R (package: lavaan or nlme) and Mplus.

As mentioned previously, we will control for any unusual spikes or dips in the data during the COVID-19 pandemic using the questions added in March (the third wave).

attributes.title: Framing effects on the effectiveness and virality of health messages related to COVID-19
attributes.description: Autonomy has been described as a fundamental human need and satisfying the need for autonomy is an important motivator of behavior (Deci & Ryan, 2000). Autonomy can be supported in various ways, and autonomy-supportive environments are associated with more successful behavior change (Ng et al., 2012). Framing information and decisions in autonomous ways, emphasizing choice and agency, may increase receptivity to health messages and promote behavior change. In this study, we assess the degree to which framing health messages related to COVID-19 in ways that support autonomy improves message effectiveness and promotes social distancing behaviors.
